title: Dick Jones (actor)
text:
Richard Percy Jones (February 25, 1927 – July 7, 2014), known as Dick Jones or Dickie Jones, was an American actor and singer who achieved success as a <a href="child%20actor">child performer</a> and as a young adult, especially in <a href="B-movie">B-Westerns</a>. In 1938, he played Artimer "Artie" Peters, nephew of Buck Peters, in the <a href="Hopalong%20Cassidy">Hopalong Cassidy</a> film "The Frontiersman". He may be best known as the voice of <a href="Pinocchio">Pinocchio</a> in <a href="Walt%20Disney">Walt Disney</a>'s <a href="Pinocchio%20%281940%20film%29">film of the same name</a>.
Early life.
Jones was born on February 25, 1927, in <a href="Snyder%2C%20Texas">Snyder</a>, some ninety miles south of <a href="Lubbock%2C%20Texas">Lubbock</a>, Texas. The son of a newspaper editor, Jones was a prodigious horseman from infancy, having been billed at the age of four as the "World's Youngest Trick Rider and Trick Roper". At the age of six, he was hired to perform riding and <a href="lasso">lariat</a> tricks in the <a href="rodeo">rodeo</a> owned by <a href="Western%20%28genre%29">western</a> star <a href="Hoot%20Gibson">Hoot Gibson</a>, who convinced young Jones and his parents that he should come to Hollywood. Jones and his mother moved there, and Gibson arranged for some small parts for the boy, whose good looks, energy, and pleasant voice quickly landed him more and bigger parts, both in low-budget westerns as well as in more substantial productions.
Career.
Among his early films are "<a href="Little%20Men%20%281934%20film%29">Little Men</a>" (1934) and "<a href="A%20Man%20to%20Remember">A Man to Remember</a>" (1938). Jones appeared as a bit player in several of <a href="Hal%20Roach">Hal Roach</a>'s "<a href="Our%20Gang">Our Gang</a>" ("The Little Rascals") shorts, including "<a href="The%20Pigskin%20Palooka">The Pigskin Palooka</a>" and "<a href="Our%20Gang%20Follies%20of%201938">Our Gang Follies of 1938</a>" (both from 1937). In 1939, Jones appeared as a troublesome kid, Killer Parkins, in the film "<a href="Nancy%20Drew...%20Reporter">Nancy Drew... Reporter</a>". The same year he appeared with <a href="Jimmy%20Stewart">Jimmy Stewart</a> in "<a href="Mr.%20Smith%20Goes%20to%20Washington">Mr. Smith Goes to Washington</a>" as Senate page Richard (Dick) Jones. In 1940, he had one of his most prominent (though invisible) roles, as the voice of Pinocchio in <a href="Pinocchio%20%281940%20film%29">Disney's animated film of the same name</a>. Jones attended <a href="Hollywood%20High%20School">Hollywood High School</a> and at fifteen took over the role of <a href="Henry%20Aldrich%20%28character%29">Henry Aldrich</a> on the hit radio show "<a href="The%20Aldrich%20Family">The Aldrich Family</a>". He learned carpentry and augmented his income with jobs in that field. He served in the <a href="United%20States%20Army">Army</a> in the <a href="Alaska%20Territory">Alaska Territory</a> during the final months of <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>.
<a href="Gene%20Autry">Gene Autry</a>, who before the war had cast Jones in several westerns, put him back to work through Autry's Flying A Pictures and, for television, his <a href="Flying%20A%20Productions">Flying A Productions</a>. Jones guest-starred regularly on "<a href="The%20Gene%20Autry%20Show">The Gene Autry Show</a>" in the early 1950s.
He appeared in a 1950 episode of the TV series "<a href="The%20Lone%20Ranger%20%28TV%20series%29">The Lone Ranger</a>" titled "Man Without a Gun". In 1950, at the age of twenty-three, he played the 16-year-old cook for a small <a href="Confederate%20States%20of%20America">Confederate Army</a> unit in the film "<a href="Rocky%20Mountain%20%28film%29">Rocky Mountain</a>".
By 1951, he was billed as Dick Jones, and starred as Dick West, sidekick to the Western hero known as "<a href="The%20Range%20Rider">The Range Rider</a>", played by <a href="Jock%20Mahoney">Jock Mahoney</a>, in a Gene Autry television series that ran for seventy-six episodes in <a href="Television%20syndication">syndication</a>, beginning in 1951.
Jones was cast thereafter in 1954 and 1955 in four episodes of "<a href="Annie%20Oakley%20%28TV%20series%29">Annie Oakley</a>", another Flying A Production. Autry gave Jones his own series, "<a href="Buffalo%20Bill%2C%20Jr.">Buffalo Bill, Jr.</a>" (1955), which ran for forty-two episodes in syndication.
Through his work in Western films and television series from the 1930s through the 1950s, Jones became a fixture at the former <a href="Iverson%20Movie%20Ranch">Iverson Movie Ranch</a>, considered the most heavily filmed outdoor shooting location in Hollywood history. In 1957, Jones appeared twice as Ned in the episodes "The Brothers" and "Renegade Rangers" of the syndicated <a href="American%20Civil%20War">American Civil War</a> series "<a href="Gray%20Ghost%20%28TV%20series%29">Gray Ghost</a>".
In 1960, Jones guest-starred as Bliss in the episode "Fire Flight" of another syndicated series, "The Blue Angels", about the elite air-show squadron of the <a href="United%20States%20Navy">United States Navy</a>. He also appeared in the syndicated western series, "<a href="Pony%20Express%20%28TV%20series%29">Pony Express</a>". In 1962, Jones portrayed John Hunter in the episode "The Wagon Train Mutiny" of NBC's Western series "<a href="Wagon%20Train">Wagon Train</a>". That same year, he appeared in the television short "The Night Rider".
Jones's last acting role was as Cliff Fletcher in the 1965 film "<a href="Requiem%20for%20a%20Gunfighter">Requiem for a Gunfighter</a>".
Honors.
In 2000, Dick Jones was named one of the <a href="Disney%20Legends">Disney Legends</a>. In early 2009, Jones performed promotional events for the Platinum Edition DVD and Blu-ray release of "Pinocchio". In March 2009, he was a guest star at the <a href="Williamsburg%2C%20Virginia">Williamsburg Film Festival</a>.
Personal life.
Jones married his wife Betty in 1948, together they have four children; Rick, Jeffrey, Jennifer and Melody. They remained married until Jones' death in 2014.
Death.
Jones died after a fall at his home on the evening of July 7, 2014, at the age of 87.
